skills.name: Pivot Patterns
skills.description:
Most successful startups pivoted. Instagram was a check-in app. Slack was
a game. YouTube was a dating site. The ability to recognize when to pivot
and execute the pivot without losing momentum is a core founder skill.

This skill covers pivot signals, types of pivots, preserving momentum during
change, and communicating pivots to investors and team.

principles.name: Pivot from learning, not frustration
principles.description:
Pivoting because things are hard is wrong. Pivoting because you learned
something is right. Every pivot should be backed by evidence, not emotions.

examples.good: After 100 user interviews, clear pattern shows different problem worth solving
examples.bad: Growth is slow, lets try something else this week

principles.name: Preserve what works
principles.description:
Good pivots keep something - the team, the technology, the insight, the
customers. Full restarts are rarely necessary. Find what to keep.

examples.good: Pivot from consumer to B2B keeping core tech and team
examples.bad: Throw everything away and start completely fresh

principles.name: Speed matters more than certainty
principles.description:
Once you decide to pivot, execute fast. Analysis paralysis during pivots
burns runway without learning. Commit and move.

examples.good: Decision made Monday, new landing page Wednesday, outreach Friday
examples.bad: Three months debating which pivot direction

principles.name: Communicate with conviction
principles.description:
Pivots create uncertainty. Leadership requires projecting confidence even
when uncertain. Share the learning that drove the pivot. Own the decision.

examples.good: We learned X, which means Y is a bigger opportunity. Here is the plan.
examples.bad: I guess the last thing was not working so we are trying this now

principles.name: One pivot at a time
principles.description:
Change one variable at a time. Market, product, or business model. Changing
everything at once makes learning impossible.

examples.good: Keep same customers, new product
examples.bad: New customers, new product, new business model simultaneously

anti_patterns.name: Pivot addiction
anti_patterns.description: Constantly changing direction before learning
anti_patterns.example: New idea every few weeks, never committing long enough to learn
anti_patterns.why_bad: Thrashing without progress. Team whiplash. No deep learning.
anti_patterns.fix: Minimum commitment periods. 6-8 weeks before evaluating.

anti_patterns.name: Ignoring signals
anti_patterns.description: Persisting despite clear evidence it is not working
anti_patterns.example: 200 user interviews saying no, still building the same thing
anti_patterns.why_bad: Hope is not a strategy. Evidence matters. Runway burns.
anti_patterns.fix: Define upfront what evidence would trigger pivot consideration.

anti_patterns.name: Stealth pivot
anti_patterns.description: Pivoting without communicating to investors or team
anti_patterns.example: Quietly building something different, hoping no one notices
anti_patterns.why_bad: Trust destroyed when discovered. Misalignment compounds.
anti_patterns.fix: Proactive communication. Share learning and reasoning.

anti_patterns.name: Pivot as blame
anti_patterns.description: Blaming the market or idea instead of learning from it
anti_patterns.example: That market was bad, this new market will be better
anti_patterns.why_bad: Same mistakes in new market. No actual learning.
anti_patterns.fix: Extract learnings. What did we get wrong? What will we do differently?

anti_patterns.name: Keeping the wrong people
anti_patterns.description: Pivoting strategy but keeping team misaligned with new direction
anti_patterns.example: Pivoting to B2B but keeping consumer-focused team
anti_patterns.why_bad: Culture and skill mismatch. Slow execution. Resentment.
anti_patterns.fix: Honest assessment of team fit. Hard conversations early.

anti_patterns.name: Pivot Addiction
anti_patterns.description: Constantly changing direction before learning anything
anti_patterns.why: Thrashing without progress. Team whiplash. No depth. No moat.
anti_patterns.instead: Minimum 6-8 week commitment before evaluating. Let learning accumulate.

anti_patterns.name: Ignoring Evidence
anti_patterns.description: Persisting despite overwhelming signals it's not working
anti_patterns.why: Hope is not a strategy. Evidence matters. Runway burns while you deny reality.
anti_patterns.instead: Define upfront what evidence would trigger pivot consideration. Honor it.

anti_patterns.name: Stealth Pivot
anti_patterns.description: Pivoting without communicating to investors or team
anti_patterns.why: Trust destroyed when discovered. Misalignment compounds. Support evaporates.
anti_patterns.instead: Proactive communication. Share the learning. Bring people along.

anti_patterns.name: Blame Pivot
anti_patterns.description: Blaming market or idea instead of extracting learnings
anti_patterns.why: Same mistakes in new market. No actual growth. Pattern repeats.
anti_patterns.instead: What did we learn? What will we do differently? Show the evolution.

anti_patterns.name: Complete Restart
anti_patterns.description: Throwing everything away instead of preserving assets
anti_patterns.why: Wastes accumulated value. Demoralizes team. Starts from zero.
anti_patterns.instead: Identify what's working. Keep team, tech, relationships, insights. Build on them.

anti_patterns.name: Multi-Variable Pivot
anti_patterns.description: Changing customer, product, and business model simultaneously
anti_patterns.why: Impossible to learn what worked or didn't. Too many variables.
anti_patterns.instead: Change one thing at a time. Test. Learn. Then change next variable.

patterns.name: Learning-Driven Pivot
patterns.description: Pivot based on accumulated evidence and user insights, not frustration
patterns.when: Data shows clear pattern indicating different opportunity
patterns.example:
After 100 user interviews, consistent pattern emerges: they need X not Y
Instagram: Check-in app → Photo filters (users only used photos)
YouTube: Dating site → Video sharing (people just shared videos)
Evidence accumulates. Pattern becomes clear. Pivot with conviction.

patterns.name: Preserve the Asset
patterns.description: Keep what's working (team, tech, customers, insight) while changing what's not
patterns.when: Executing any pivot to maintain momentum
patterns.example:
Slack: Game failed, but team communication tool worked → Kept tech, changed market
Twitter: Podcasting platform failed → Kept status update feature, dropped rest
What do you have that's valuable? Build the pivot around it.

patterns.name: Zoom-In Pivot
patterns.description: Make one successful feature into the entire product
patterns.when: One feature shows significantly stronger engagement than others
patterns.example:
Instagram: Photo filters in check-in app → Just filters
Burbn had check-in, photos, points → Pivoted to just photo sharing
What do users actually use? Make that the whole product.

patterns.name: Customer Segment Pivot
patterns.description: Keep the product, change who you sell it to
patterns.when: Wrong customer segment but right solution
patterns.example:
Slack: Built for gamers → Sold to businesses
Yammer: Built for company-wide → Sold to teams
Who has the money and pain? Go there, even if it wasn't your original plan.

patterns.name: Speed Over Certainty
patterns.description: Once pivot decision is made, execute fast and learn quickly
patterns.when: Pivot decision has been made with sufficient evidence
patterns.example:
Decision Monday → New landing page Wednesday → User outreach Friday
Indecision burns runway. Make the call. Move fast. Learn.
Perfect pivot plan doesn't exist. Good enough plan executed fast wins.

patterns.name: Narrative Control
patterns.description: Frame the pivot as evolution based on learning, not failure
patterns.when: Communicating pivot to team, investors, and users
patterns.example:
"We learned X, which led us to discover Y is the bigger opportunity"
Not: "The last thing didn't work so we're trying this now"
Own the narrative. Show the learning. Demonstrate momentum.

frameworks.name: Types of Pivots
structure: Zoom-in: One feature becomes the product
Zoom-out: Product becomes one feature of bigger product
Customer segment: Same product, different customer
Customer need: Same customer, different need
Platform: Product becomes platform
Business model: Same product, different monetization
Channel: Same product, different go-to-market
Technology: Same value prop, different technology

frameworks.name: Pivot Decision Framework
structure: Have you talked to 50+ users about the problem?
Is there a clear pattern in why it is not working?
Did you discover a better opportunity during research?
Do you have sufficient runway to execute a pivot?
Is the team aligned on the need to change?
frameworks.notes: Need strong yes on most to justify pivot

frameworks.name: Pivot Execution Checklist
structure: Document learnings from previous direction
Define hypothesis for new direction
Communicate to team with conviction
Update investors with learning story
Adjust hiring and priorities
Set clear milestones for new direction
Preserve assets and relationships that transfer

frameworks.name: Investor Communication Template
structure: What we learned: The data and insights that changed our view
The opportunity: Why new direction is bigger or better
What transfers: Team, tech, insights we are keeping
The plan: Milestones and timeline for new direction
The ask: What support we need from investors

validations.name: Pivot Without Success Criteria
validations.message: Pivot mentioned but no success criteria defined. How will you know if the pivot worked?
validations.fix_action: Define measurable criteria: what metrics, what thresholds, what timeframe to evaluate

validations.name: Pivot Without Evaluation Timeline
validations.message: Experiment mentioned without timeline. Experiments without deadlines become indefinite wandering.
validations.fix_action: Set kill date: 'We will evaluate on [date] and decide to commit, iterate, or abandon'

validations.name: Sunk Cost Reasoning Detected
validations.message: Sunk cost language detected. Past investment is not a reason to continue. Evaluate future potential only.
validations.fix_action: Ask: If starting fresh today with current knowledge, would we choose this path?

validations.name: Pivot Without Customer Evidence
validations.message: Strategic change without customer evidence. Pivots should be driven by data, not intuition.
validations.fix_action: Document: what customers said, usage data, churn reasons, willingness to pay signals

validations.name: Pivot Without Killing Features
validations.message: Adding without removing detected. True pivots require focus. You cannot pivot while keeping everything.
validations.fix_action: Define what you are stopping: features, segments, channels. Pivoting means choosing.

validations.name: Pivot Without Runway Consideration
validations.message: Pivot discussed without runway check. Pivots cost time and money. Do you have enough?
validations.fix_action: Calculate: runway remaining, burn during pivot, time to new revenue. Can you afford this pivot?

validations.name: Total Rebuild Pivot Risk
validations.message: Total rebuild language detected. Full rewrites are almost always wrong. Preserve what works.
validations.fix_action: Identify reusable assets: tech, customers, learnings, relationships. Build on them.

validations.name: Pivot Without Team Alignment
validations.message: Strategic decision without team alignment process. Misaligned teams execute poorly.
validations.fix_action: Ensure everyone understands: why pivoting, what changing, their new role, success criteria

validations.name: Competitor-Driven Pivot
validations.message: Competitor-driven reasoning detected. Pivoting because competitors are doing X is follower strategy.
validations.fix_action: Ground in your customer evidence. What do YOUR customers need that is unserved?

validations.name: Pivot Without Stakeholder Communication
validations.message: Pivot without communication plan. Investors, customers, team all need to understand the change.
validations.fix_action: Define communication: who to tell, what narrative, when to announce, how to handle questions

validations.name: Assuming New Market is Easier
validations.message: Grass is greener thinking detected. Every market has its own challenges. The new market is not easier, just different.
validations.fix_action: Research new market deeply: competitors, barriers, customer acquisition cost, sales cycle

validations.name: Discarding All Learnings
validations.message: Discarding learnings language detected. Even failed experiments teach you something valuable.
validations.fix_action: Document learnings: what worked, what did not, customer insights, technical assets to keep

cross_domain_insights.insight:
Navigators know course correction:
- Small adjustments early
- Use landmarks
- Current affects course
- Destination remains fixed
Pivots are course corrections, not restarts.

Evolution teaches adaptation:
- Preserve what works
- Variation creates options
- Environment selects winners
- Gradual beats sudden
Business pivots follow evolutionary patterns.

Jazz musicians know improvisation:
- Changes are opportunities
- Respond to the moment
- Keep the groove
- Build on what came before
Pivots are strategic improvisation.

skills.name: Product Strategy
skills.description:
World-class product strategy expertise combining Marty Cagan's outcome-driven
product management, Steve Jobs' product intuition, and modern Silicon Valley
best practices. This skill answers the fundamental question: "What should we
build and why will it win?"

This is not about features or roadmaps. It's about discovering what customers
desperately need but can't articulate, and building something 10x better than
alternatives.
principles: Fall in love with the problem, not the solution
The best products are painkillers, not vitamins
If you're not embarrassed by v1, you launched too late
Strategy is what you say no to
Products are not built, they are discovered
skills.identity:
You are a product strategist who has built multiple $100M+ products. You've
seen thousands of products fail and know exactly why. You combine rigorous
frameworks with gut instinct honed over decades. You're allergic to feature
factories and "me too" products. You push back hard on solutions before
understanding problems deeply. You know that most product failures come from
building the wrong thing, not building the thing wrong.

patterns.name: Jobs-to-be-Done Framework
patterns.description: Define products in terms of the job customers hire them to do
patterns.when: Starting product discovery or reframing an existing product
patterns.example:
# Job Statement Template
When [situation], I want to [motivation], so I can [expected outcome].

# Example: Music Streaming
When I'm commuting to work, I want to discover music that matches my mood,
so I can make the journey more enjoyable.

# Forces Analysis
Push: Current frustrations driving change
Pull: Desired benefits attracting to new solution
Anxiety: Fears about switching
Habit: Comfort with current solution

patterns.name: Problem Validation Ladder
patterns.description: Systematically validate problem severity before building
patterns.when: Before writing any code or defining features
patterns.example:
Level 1: Problem exists (people mention it unprompted)
Level 2: Problem is painful (they've tried solutions)
Level 3: Problem is urgent (they'll pay/switch now)
Level 4: Problem is frequent (happens often enough to care)

Validation: 5+ customer interviews at each level
Kill criterion: Can't find 5 people at Level 3

patterns.name: Value Proposition Canvas
patterns.description: Map customer pains/gains to your product's relief/creation
patterns.when: Defining why customers would choose your product
patterns.example:
Customer Profile:
  Jobs: What are they trying to accomplish?
  Pains: What frustrates them about current solutions?
  Gains: What would delight them?

Value Map:
  Products/Services: What you offer
  Pain Relievers: How you address pains
  Gain Creators: How you deliver gains

Fit = Pain Relievers match Pains, Gain Creators match Gains

patterns.name: Competitive Positioning Matrix
patterns.description: Position against competition on axes that matter to customers
patterns.when: Defining differentiation strategy
patterns.example:
1. List key buying criteria from customer interviews
2. Pick 2 criteria where you can win AND customers care
3. Plot competitors on these two axes
4. Find the white space or pick a defensible quadrant

Example axes:
  - Price vs. Quality (avoid this - obvious)
  - Speed vs. Customization (better)
  - Self-serve vs. High-touch (better)

patterns.name: MVP Scoping with Sean Ellis Test
patterns.description: Define MVP as minimum needed to reach 40% "very disappointed"
patterns.when: Scoping v1 or deciding what to cut
patterns.example:
After users try your product, ask:
"How would you feel if you could no longer use this product?"

Options: Very disappointed, Somewhat disappointed, Not disappointed

Target: 40%+ "very disappointed"

MVP = minimum features to hit 40%
Cut ruthlessly anything that doesn't contribute

anti_patterns.name: Solution-First Thinking
anti_patterns.description: Jumping to features before deeply understanding the problem
anti_patterns.why: 80% of product failures come from solving the wrong problem, not building wrong
anti_patterns.instead: Spend 70% of discovery on problem, 30% on solution

anti_patterns.name: Feature Factory Roadmap
anti_patterns.description: Planning roadmaps as lists of features instead of outcomes
anti_patterns.why: Features are guesses; you don't know what will work until you ship
anti_patterns.instead: Define outcomes (metrics to move), let teams discover features

anti_patterns.name: The Everything MVP
anti_patterns.description: MVP that tries to serve all use cases and user segments
anti_patterns.why: Trying to be everything means being nothing - no one loves it
anti_patterns.instead: Pick ONE job for ONE user segment and nail it completely

anti_patterns.name: Competitive Feature Matching
anti_patterns.description: Adding features because competitors have them
anti_patterns.why: You'll always be behind, and it ignores why customers choose you
anti_patterns.instead: Compete on a different axis where you can be 10x better

anti_patterns.name: Survey-Driven Discovery
anti_patterns.description: Relying on surveys instead of customer interviews
anti_patterns.why: Surveys tell you what people say, not what they do or feel
anti_patterns.instead: 1-on-1 interviews with open questions, observe behavior

anti_patterns.name: Building for Power Users
anti_patterns.description: Prioritizing features for your most vocal/engaged users
anti_patterns.why: Power users aren't representative; you'll over-complicate for normals
anti_patterns.instead: Prioritize based on problem frequency across all segments

handoffs.context: User is working on brand strategy and messaging
User is working on growth tactics after PMF

handoffs.trigger: copy or headlines or value prop writing

validations.name: No User Problem Defined
validations.message: Product work without defined user problem. What pain are you solving? For whom? Be specific.
validations.fix_action: Define the problem: What struggle do users have? How painful? How frequent? How do they cope today?

validations.name: Feature-Focused Strategy
validations.message: Feature list as strategy. Features are not strategy. Strategy is choosing what problems to solve and why.
validations.fix_action: Focus on outcomes: What can users achieve? What jobs does this help them do? Why does it matter?

validations.name: No Product Success Criteria
validations.message: Shipping without success criteria. How will you know if it worked? Define metrics before building.
validations.fix_action: Set criteria: usage metric, retention target, revenue goal, NPS score? Make success measurable.

validations.name: Competitor Feature Copycat
validations.message: Building features because competitors have them. Copying is not strategy. It's the opposite of differentiation.
validations.fix_action: Ask: Does this solve OUR users' problem uniquely? Or are we just following? Lead, don't follow.

validations.name: No User Validation Plan
validations.message: Product idea without validation plan. Ideas are cheap. Evidence is valuable. How will you test this?
validations.fix_action: Plan validation: Who will you talk to? What will you build to test? What evidence proves/disproves this?

validations.name: Kitchen Sink Product
validations.message: Trying to do everything. Products that do everything serve no one well. What is your core value?
validations.fix_action: Cut ruthlessly: What ONE thing will you be the best at? What will you NOT do? Focus creates value.

validations.name: No Product Tradeoffs
validations.message: No tradeoffs mentioned. Every product decision is a tradeoff. What are you optimizing for? What are you sacrificing?
validations.fix_action: Be explicit: Fast OR perfect? Simple OR powerful? Cheap OR premium? Choose. Tradeoffs define products.

validations.name: No MVP Definition
validations.message: MVP mentioned without clear scope. What's the MINIMUM that proves value? Not minimum everything.
validations.fix_action: Define MVP: smallest thing that solves core problem for early users. One job, done well. Ship that first.

validations.name: Trying to Boil the Ocean
validations.message: Platform/marketplace as V1. These require network effects. Impossible to bootstrap. Start smaller.
validations.fix_action: Start single-player: What value can one user get alone? Build that first. Layer on network effects later.

validations.name: No Delivery Timeline
validations.message: Product work without timeline. How long will this take? When will users see value? Be realistic.
validations.fix_action: Set timeline: What ships in 2 weeks? 1 month? 3 months? Break into phases. Ship early and often.

validations.name: Technology-First Strategy
validations.message: Technology-first thinking. Users don't care about your tech stack. They care about their problems solved.
validations.fix_action: Lead with value: What can users do? What outcome do they get? Technology is implementation detail.

validations.name: No User Research Evidence
validations.message: User needs claimed without research evidence. How do you know? Who did you talk to? Show your work.
validations.fix_action: Add evidence: X users said Y. Usage data shows Z. Support tickets mention A. Real data, not assumptions.

Product strategy is applied military strategy.

VCs know markets:
- Market size determines ceiling
- Timing matters more than ideas
- Distribution is everything
- Power law dominates returns
Product strategy must pass VC scrutiny.

Designers know users:
- Observe, don't just ask
- Prototype to learn
- Embrace constraints
- Iterate rapidly
Strategy emerges from deep user understanding.

skills.name: Taste and Craft
skills.description:
Good taste is knowing what is good. Craft is making it real. Together they
separate products people tolerate from products people love. Paul Graham's
essays explore how taste develops and why it matters.

This skill synthesizes PG's wisdom on quality, simplicity, and the details
that separate great from good.

principles.name: Taste is learned, not innate
principles.description:
Taste is knowing what is good. It can be developed. Study great work.
Understand why it is great. Compare to lesser work. See the difference.
Taste grows through exposure and analysis.

examples.good: Studying great products, understanding principles, applying them
examples.bad: Assuming taste is innate, not investing in developing it

principles.name: Simple is hard
principles.description:
Simplicity requires understanding what is essential. Anyone can add
complexity. Removing it requires knowing what matters. Simple solutions
are not lazy - they are the hardest to achieve.
principles.source: Six Principles for Making New Things

examples.good: Feature works perfectly with minimal UI, obvious how to use
examples.bad: Feature has many options, settings, configurations

principles.name: Details reveal care
principles.description:
Users notice when details are right, even if they cannot articulate why.
Misaligned elements, inconsistent spacing, awkward copy - these signal
lack of care. Getting details right signals quality throughout.

examples.good: Every element aligned, every interaction smooth, every word intentional
examples.bad: Close enough, ship it, users will not notice

principles.name: Good people make good things
principles.description:
Quality of work reflects quality of people and culture. Hire people who
care about craft. Create environment where quality matters. Be good,
and you will make good things.

examples.good: Team debates details, pushes for better, celebrates quality
examples.bad: Team ships minimum viable, nobody cares about craft

principles.name: Timeless over trendy
principles.description:
Trends pass. Timeless principles endure. Simple, clean, bold choices
last. Gimmicks date. Build for 10 years, not 10 months.
principles.source: Six Principles for Making New Things

examples.good: Design that looked good 5 years ago and will look good in 5 years
examples.bad: Following current design trends that will look dated soon

anti_patterns.name: Complexity as sophistication
anti_patterns.description: Adding complexity to seem advanced
anti_patterns.example: Many features, many options, many settings
anti_patterns.why_bad: Users want simplicity. Complexity is often laziness in disguise.
anti_patterns.fix: Remove until it breaks. What is the minimum that delivers value?

anti_patterns.name: Quality later
anti_patterns.description: Assuming you can add quality after shipping
anti_patterns.example: Ship fast, polish later (later never comes)
anti_patterns.why_bad: Quality is a habit, not a phase. Patterns set early persist.
anti_patterns.fix: Build quality in from the start. Slower initially, faster overall.

anti_patterns.name: Ignoring details
anti_patterns.description: Dismissing small imperfections as unimportant
anti_patterns.example: Slightly off alignment, typos, inconsistent styles
anti_patterns.why_bad: Users feel it even if they cannot articulate it. Trust erodes.
anti_patterns.fix: Sweat the details. They are the surface of deeper quality.

anti_patterns.name: Trend chasing
anti_patterns.description: Adopting whatever is currently popular
anti_patterns.example: Redesigning to match latest design trends every year
anti_patterns.why_bad: Constant change is disorienting. Trends date quickly.
anti_patterns.fix: Choose timeless principles. Update rarely and intentionally.

anti_patterns.name: Taste as elitism
anti_patterns.description: Using taste to dismiss or exclude
anti_patterns.example: Rejecting input because user does not have taste
anti_patterns.why_bad: Taste should elevate, not exclude. Users know when things work.
anti_patterns.fix: Use taste to make things better for everyone.

patterns.name: Taste Development Practice
patterns.description: Study great work systematically to develop taste over time
patterns.when: Building your ability to recognize and create quality
patterns.example:
30 min daily: Analyze excellent products, understand why they're great
Compare great and mediocre side-by-side. See the differences.
Taste is learned through exposure and analysis, not innate.

patterns.name: Simplicity Discipline
patterns.description: Remove everything possible until it breaks, then add back one element
patterns.when: Making design and product decisions
patterns.example:
Feature works perfectly with minimal UI, obvious how to use
Not: Many options, settings, configurations
Simple is hard. Anyone can add. Removing requires understanding essence.

patterns.name: Detail Obsession
patterns.description: Sweat every small detail as signal of overall quality
patterns.when: Reviewing work before shipping
patterns.example:
Alignment, spacing, word choice, interaction timing
Users feel quality in details even if they can't articulate it
Details reveal care. Getting them right signals quality throughout.

patterns.name: Timeless Over Trendy
patterns.description: Choose design principles that age well over current trends
patterns.when: Making aesthetic and architectural decisions
patterns.example:
Would this have looked good 5 years ago? Will it look good in 5 years?
Trends date quickly. Timeless principles endure.
Build for 10 years, not 10 months.

patterns.name: Quality as Habit
patterns.description: Build quality in from the start, not as a later polish phase
patterns.when: Beginning any project or feature
patterns.example:
Quality first, even if slower initially. Pattern compounds.
Not: Ship fast, polish later (later never comes)
Quality is a practice, not a phase. Start as you mean to continue.

patterns.name: Good People Make Good Things
patterns.description: Hire people who care about craft and create culture where quality matters
patterns.when: Building team and culture
patterns.example:
Team debates details, pushes for better, celebrates quality
Not: Minimum viable, nobody cares about craft
Quality of output reflects quality of people and culture.

frameworks.name: PG Six Principles
structure: Simple: Can this be simpler? Remove everything possible.
Timeless: Will this feel dated in 5 years?
Daring: Is this bold enough to be interesting?
Thorough: Are all the details right?
Good: Does this actually work well?
Delightful: Does this create joy?

frameworks.name: Taste Development Practice
structure: Study great work: 30 min daily analyzing excellent products
Understand why: What makes this great? What would make it less great?
Compare: Put great and mediocre side by side. See differences.
Apply: Use insights in your own work
Get feedback: From people with better taste than you

frameworks.name: Quality Check Questions
structure: Is this as simple as possible?
Will this age well?
Do all the details feel right?
Would I be proud to show this to someone I admire?
Does this reflect the quality of our team?

frameworks.name: Timeless Design Audit
structure: Would this have looked good 10 years ago?
Will this look good 10 years from now?
Is this following a trend or a principle?
What in this might date?

validations.name: Inconsistent Naming Convention
validations.message: Inconsistent naming patterns. Craft means consistency. Pick conventions and stick to them.
validations.fix_action: Standardize: all fetchers use fetch*, all boolean getters use is*, all handlers use handle*

validations.name: Magic Values Without Context
validations.message: Magic numbers in code. Craft means intentional, documented choices.
validations.fix_action: Extract to named constants or design tokens: 16 → SPACING_MD or --spacing-md

validations.name: Duplicate Code Blocks
validations.message: Repeated code pattern detected. Craft means DRY. Duplication is a design smell.
validations.fix_action: Extract to shared function or component. One source of truth.

validations.name: Generic Error Messages
validations.message: Generic error message. Craft means helpful errors that guide users to resolution.
validations.fix_action: Specific error: 'Something went wrong' → 'Could not save. Check your connection and try again.'

validations.name: Arbitrary Z-Index Values
validations.message: Z-index arms race detected. Arbitrary high values indicate missing stacking strategy.
validations.fix_action: Create z-index scale: base(0), dropdown(10), modal(20), toast(30). Use system, not random numbers.

validations.name: Text Truncation Without Tooltip
validations.message: Text truncation without showing full content. User cannot access hidden information.
validations.fix_action: Add title attribute or tooltip to reveal full content on hover

validations.name: Loading State Without Skeleton
validations.message: Loading state detected. Spinners feel slower than skeletons. Show shape of incoming content.
validations.fix_action: Replace spinner with skeleton that matches content shape. Perceived performance matters.

validations.name: Hardcoded Color Values
validations.message: Hardcoded colors detected. Craft means systematic design tokens, not ad-hoc values.
validations.fix_action: Use design tokens: #3B82F6 → var(--color-primary) or theme.colors.primary

validations.name: Animation Without Reduced Motion Check
validations.message: Animation without reduced motion consideration. Some users get motion sick.
validations.fix_action: Add @media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce) check to disable or simplify animations

validations.name: Button Without Disabled State
validations.message: Button without disabled state handling. Users need feedback when actions are unavailable.
validations.fix_action: Add disabled prop with visual indication: lower opacity, no hover effect, cursor: not-allowed

validations.name: Form Without Validation Feedback
validations.message: Form elements detected. Craft means clear validation feedback before, during, and after submit.
validations.fix_action: Add inline validation, clear error messages, and success confirmation

validations.name: Inconsistent Spacing Values
validations.message: Non-standard spacing values. Craft means systematic spacing scale (4, 8, 12, 16, 24, 32...).
validations.fix_action: Use spacing scale: 5px → 4px or 8px. Consistency creates visual harmony.
